title: A Cherished Friendship: Julia Griffiths Crofts and Frederick Douglass
abstract: Abstract Julia Griffiths' significance during the early 1850s is widely acknowledged, but little is known about her before or after her extended visit to Rochester. This article presents new information about her family background. It traces her public career as an anti-slavery activist following her departure from the United States in 1855, providing details of the women's anti-slavery groups she helped establish, and, following her marriage in 1859, her departure from the public stage, and return to the writing and fund-raising she had done while in Rochester.
